But! I think the take home message of this article is actually less about LoL specifically and more about the fact that college courses that are related to games/hobbies/crafts/things students **like** don't _have_ to be "filler." Imagine if your archery class had analysis of the physics involved as a part of it. Half the kids would probably flunk it! But more importantly they would be challenged to learn something they may not have otherwise studied, and they probably would be far more engaged in the physics in that type of setting because it's practical, it's directly applicable to the what they enjoy doing, and everyone loves shooting arrows at things! #supportashe

Yes, this course is about vidya, but not only is vidya **big** business these days, it's highly technological, social, mathematical, psychological too. That's academic AND practical. And that's where education is heading these days. The days of silly word problems like "Gragas has 37,412 watermelons each with approximately 17cm diameter and needs to know the specific gravity of the soluble solids in the watermelons to calculate his watermelon moonshine formula. Do math." type of learning are becoming a thing of the past. We know people learn in different ways, we know there are _a lot_ of kinesthetic learners out there. And we know people better retain theories/concepts when they are interested in the subject, and see the real world application of the theory/concept.

I think archery is interesting for some, just as this League class would be interesting for some.

I'm also curious at looking at League (this is the only game I play) along with other games that have really impacted human relations as far as you and your best friend, to whole countries! I would be curious to also look at League at a more socialistic view. 

I think I'm rambling now...I'm sorry. But I wanted to reply to basically say I agree!!

The way courses like this are offered at UC Berkeley is through a system called Decal (http://www.decal.org/). The system is meant to be a way for students to create and facilitate courses on various subjects. Decals do not satisfy any requirements for any major, and the only thing you get out of it from the perspective of college is college units. For instance, most decals are worth 1-2 units (a typical class is worth 3-4 units). Students often elect to take decals out of interest in the topic and/or to meet minimum unit requirements per semester.

I'm in college and spend too much time playing video games, but even I think this is an absolute joke. Why isn't this a class about the video game industry? Learning about the business, economic, social, artistic, etc aspect of video games in general.

Just because LoL is popular and takes a degree of thought that doesn't mean it should be made into a legitimate class... 

How is this any less ridiculous than the idea of a school teaching:

- World of Warcraft
- DoTA
- Guild Wars 2
- Hearthstone 
- Sid Meier's Civilization
- Starcraft
- The Elder Scrolls
- Minecraft
- Team Fortress 2
- Halo 
- Call of Duty 
- Dark Souls 
- Chess
- Poker
- Checkers
- Pictionary

Although it may not have been made clear in the interviews above, the majority of the class is actually about the industry of video games :) In fact, we had weekly topics on almost all of the topics you mentioned: 2 weeks on player contracts+eSports development (business/econ), psychology (social), 2 weeks on champion design + art design (artistic), as well as a few others! 

This class isn't about developing game mechanics. People can do that on their own, and the only way to get good at LoL is by practice. We wanted our class to have significance outside of League of Legends, a goal which I believe we accomplished!

On the contrary, I feel like some of the games you have listed, for example, Sid Meier's Civilization, Chess, Poker, Minecraft, and more have potentials to be taught in a class, of course with the assumption that the class won't be based on HOW to play the games. The interesting fact about the LoL class taught at UCBerkeley was analyzing how League has impacted society as whole (for example in psychology, art, creativity, communication, and more as AP Sona had mentioned.) Video games don't have to just be "games," with a connotation of zero value outside of entertainment; they can be a resource utilized to analyze how different disciplines connect. It's not a traditional way of teaching, but it shows promise when done the right way. (At least that is what I believe)

Hey Meph! As an alumni of Cal (UC Berkeley) and a former facilitator for a previous iteration of the course, I can provide some insight on this.

The course is run as a Decal at Berkeley (http://www.decal.org/) so the main facilitators are required to be students at Cal. However, if you do have a level of expertise that you can offer beyond the facilitators, I recommend you reaching out to future facilitators and asking if you could be a guest speaker for a class! If the class is offered in the future, be sure to check the Decal website and see how you can contact the facilitators about opportunities to teach!

I'm a little confused... "Expressing your opinion is fine", but not when your opinion is adversarial? I respectfully disagree. I find that speech is most valuable when it dissents from the majority, albeit in a respectful and constructive manner (I don't disagree with you that those posting that this is "dumb as f**k" should simply keep their comments to themselves until they are willing to contribute some meaningful message to the conversation). I truly wish people would stop down-voting posts simply because they disagree; the down-vote system is intended to be a way to remove posts that are toxic or designed to incite anger rather than discourse. Also, your statement saying "if you don't like it go read a different thread" mildly upsets me; this is the same line of reasoning used by individuals stating "if you don't like our country, move somewhere else." Is that to be our new stance, that we wish only to hear people who agree with us express their opinions, and those who disagree should go elsewhere and collude together? This mindset stifles the flow of information, reasoning, and directly hinders constructive debate and problem solving.

You also state in your initial paragraph that this class has merit because its something people would "rather do" in college; while I can appreciate this statement, I think it misconstrues the purpose of college _courses_. Yes, college can and should be fun and entertaining, but the subject material of the course itself should pertain to fields applicable to the students future, either in general or major specific. The problem with courses such as this are that they provide a significant distraction to students, legitimizing a recreational pass time as a scholastic activity, thus validating the off-time substitution of gaming for actual school work. Simply by offering this as a course with credits, rather than a club or student group, the college has given an implicit green light for students to dedicate large portions of their time to gaming. To clarify: i'm a gamer (obviously, as I'm posting on this forum), but games, on my list of priorities, are by necessity lower than productive educational pursuits; the inclusion of such a class in a college's offerings upsets this value hierarchy, blurring the line for impressionable young students.

I don't hate the idea of this course, but I do seriously worry about the implementation of it, as well as the precedent set by this college in allowing a course of this type to be both created _and_ taught by students. I personally fail to see the value this course brings as a class that could not be garnered via club formation.
